question_details.query: When restoring grasslands, how do the outcomes of simply disturbing the soil before seeding compare to removing the topsoil entirely?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies, disturbing the soil before seeding produced mixed effects on plant richness and diversity (increases in one of two studies; no change in the other) and did not change total plant biomass, though it increased forb cover in one study and often improved emergence; survival increased in one of two studies and seedling growth showed no effect [3413]. In contrast, removing topsoil or turf before seeding/planting increased overall plant species richness and made communities more similar to intact reference steppe in a replicated study, increased richness of sown species, and, in a direct comparison, increased grass and forb species richness in most cases compared to disturbing the soil; overall vegetation cover did not change, but planted species cover was higher, common knapweed cover was lower, and seedling/plant survival of target grasses increased in two studies [3415].

These conflicting results (one showing an increase, the other showing no change) support the claim that the effects were 'mixed'.
